tiles.title: Github Projects
tiles.text: Some of my cooler github projects. Made with ♥ and fueled by coffee beans.

tiles.title: Who am i?
tiles.text: A little word or two on me.</br>Who I am, where I'm from and what I get up to.
tiles.backHTML:
Who am I?

Call me Josh. I am a software engineer hailing from Central Scotland.

I like coffee a little bit to much and as a result of this I consistantly find myself counter balancing the caffine content by writing clean and efficient code.

You’ll usually find me at the gym, breaking something (and then fixing it) or knee deep in a personal project.

This websites current purpose is to showcase some of the interesting things I’ve done. You can find a few links and demonstrations of my work displayed on this website.

Speaking of work, I am currently positioned as a middlware engineer for the NatWest group.

tiles.title: p5Gravitation
tiles.text: Manipulate gravity with your mouse, coded using the p5.js library.
tiles.backHTML:
p5Gravitation

Move the mouse or a finger around and the gravity will follow.

Scroll the wheel or adjust the top slider to vary the gravity offset.

Source code is available here.

tiles.title: jsTetris
tiles.text: A basic implementation of Tetris, coded in Python using Pygame, compiled to JavaScript using Pyjs with Pyjsdl.
tiles.backHTML:
jsTetris

Keyboard controls are as follows:

KeyAction
left arrowmove left
right arrowmove right
zrotate left
xrotate right
down arrowsoft drop
spacehard drop
ppause
rrestart

Use the buttons to the right of the grid if you lack a keyboard.

Source code is available here.

tiles.title: p5Pong
tiles.text: A simple Pong clone, coded using the p5.js library.
tiles.backHTML:
p5Pong

Move the mouse or a finger around and the left paddle will follow.

Double click inside the game window or press 'p' to (un)pause.

Source code is available here.

tiles.title: About this website
tiles.text: A little about what this website runs on and how you can create your own home server
tiles.backHTML:
About this website

This website started out as a pet project in 2017. It was originally an experiment to see if it was possible to use css transforms as a navigational tool. You can see to the right a screenshot of the original proof of concept.

The website has since evolved in to a sort of pseudo webapp. 95% of the HTML is generated on the fly. This makes it quite modular and easy to add new content.

The website is also self hosted on a thin client (pictured right). It is a type of low power device akin to a raspberry pi.

It is currently running Debian Linux and hosts a number of web services.

If you find yourself in need of a low cost, low power home server, I would highly recommend parkytowers (here) as a place to start.
